Subject: Competitive co-evolution
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=115403844
X-Yahoo-Profile: jarrowwx

The recent talk on bidding prompted an idea...

Has anyone ever trained or evolved a network where one of the outputs is 
like a 'confidence' level in that it is an estimate of the error of the rest 
of the output?

In other words, suppose you have 2 outputs.  Output A and B.  A is the real 
output.  There is an expected output for A.    There is an error value for 
A.  The expected output of B is then the error value of A.

Why bother?  Well, suppose that you have evolved 100 solutions to a problem. 
  Some are better for one kind of input, others are better at another.  You 
could let the networks themselves decide which one is best suited for a 
particular input, and you could use the correlation between estimated error 
and output values to calculate a more precise output for the whole network.

For example, network 1 has an output of 5 with an error value of (e.g.) 2.  
That means, for the sake of illustration, that the real output will be 
somewhere between 3 and 7.  A second network has an output of 7 with an 
error of 0.5.  So the real value is between 6.5 and 7.5.  If you took the 
average of the output values, the result is 6.  But if you took the center 
of the overlap, the output becomes 6.75.  That value might be much closer to 
the correct value than just the average of the two networks.

Admittedly, it forces the network to calculate a more complex function.  But 
it might be useful, who knows?
